wobani.materials

Class Material

  • java.lang.Object
    • wobani.materials.Material

  • public class Material
extends java.lang.Object
    Material for Splines and Meshes. It can work together with any kind of Renderers, you should only store the required slots in it. Note that not all Rendeers support all types of slots, but that isn't a problem if you add unsupported type of slot to a Material, the GeometryRenderer will ignore it. If you don't add a slot which is requred by a built-in GeometryRenderer, it will use some kind of a default value.

    • Method Detail

      • getRenderer

        @NotNull
public java.lang.Class<? extends GeometryRenderer> getRenderer()
        Returns the Material's GeometryRenderer class.
        Returns:
        the Material's GeometryRenderer class

      • getSlot

        @Nullable
public MaterialSlot getSlot(@NotNull
                                       java.lang.String key)
        Returns the Material's specified slot. If you use your own GeometryRenderer, you can use any String key you want. However if you use the built-in Renderers, you should use these Renderers' specified keys. You can reach these keys as this Material class's static final String values. Note that not all Rendeers support all types of slots, but that isn't a problem if you add unsupported type of slot to a Material, the GeometryRenderer will ignore it. If you don't add a slot which is requred by a built-in GeometryRenderer, it will use some kind of a default value.
        Parameters:
        key - slot's key
        Returns:
        the Material's specified slot
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - the key can't be null

      • setSlot

        public void setSlot(@NotNull
                    java.lang.String key,
                    @Nullable
                    MaterialSlot slot)
        Sets the Material's specified slot to the given value. If you use your own GeometryRenderer, you can use any String key you want. However if you use the built-in Renderers, you should use these Renderers' specified keys. You can reach these keys as this Material class's static final String values. Note that not all Rendeers support all types of slots, but that isn't a problem if you add unsupported type of slot to a Material, the GeometryRenderer will ignore it. If you don't add a slot which is requred by a built-in GeometryRenderer, it will use some kind of a default value.
        Parameters:
        key - slot's key
        slot - Material's slot
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - the key can't be null

        @Nullable
public java.lang.Float getFloatParameter(@NotNull
                                                    java.lang.String key)
        Returns the specified key's Float value. Float, String and vector parameters use distinct keys and values.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the specified key's Float value

      • setFloatParameter

        public void setFloatParameter(@NotNull
                              java.lang.String key,
                              @Nullable
                              java.lang.Float value)
        Sets the specified key's value to the given Float parameter. Note that the it doesn't check whether or not given value is valid so try to give sensable values. Float, String and vector parameters use distinct keys and values.
        Parameters:
        key - key
        value - value
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - key can't be null
